user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueuePut_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_QueuePut_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *data, size_t size, uint32 flags)
{
    int32                            return_code;
    int                              result;
    struct timespec                  ts;
    OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token);

    /*
     * NOTE - using a zero timeout here for the same reason that QueueGet does ---
     * checking the attributes and doing the actual send is non-atomic, and if
     * two threads call QueuePut() at the same time on a nearly-full queue,
     * one could block.
     */
    memset(&ts, 0, sizeof(ts));

    /* send message */
    do
    {
        result = mq_timedsend(impl->id, data, size, 1, &ts);
    } while (result == -1 && errno == EINTR);

    if (result == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else if (errno == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return_code = OS_QUEUE_FULL;
    }
    else
    {
        /* Something else went wrong */
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
int32 OS_QueuePut_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *data, size_t size, uint32 flags)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: none of the function parameters are assigned to or otherwise modified. The code dereferences the const pointer token (using *token) and passes the const data pointer to mq_timedsend, but neither the pointer variables nor the non-const parameters are written to. (Modifying the object pointed to would be allowed; here no such modification occurs.)
